<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning and Happy Birthday. </strong>We feel extremely comfortable saying that, because according to a dataset of births from 1994–2014, September 9 was the most common birth date. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We know you're wondering...nine months before September is December. </p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HUMAN RIGHTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/08/disney-criticized-nods-xinjiang-entities-inmulan?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
'Mulan' Filming Location Gets Disney in Trouble
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Human rights activists protest camps in Xinjiang" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzUwL2h1bWFuX3JpZ2h0c19hY3RpdmlzdHNfcHJvdGVzdF9jYW1wc19pbl94aW5qaWFuZy5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Pierre Crom/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you made it to the credits of Disney’s <em>Mulan</em> remake this weekend, you probably skipped right over the customary "thank yous" hoping for a bonus scene. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But some eagle-eyed viewers spotted <a href="https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-under-fire-for-filming-mulan-in-chinas-xinjiang-province?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">controversial nods</a> to eight government entities in China’s western Xinjiang region, where part of the movie was filmed. Those entities include multiple propaganda agencies on a White House blacklist for links to forced labor and human rights abuses. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What’s going on in Xinjiang?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s where China’s Communist Party <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/08/world/asia/china-mulan-xinjiang.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">has detained</a> an estimated 1+ million ethnic minorities, particularly Uighur Muslims.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">China claims it's running job-training centers and combating Islamic extremism. But numerous reports, leaks, and testimonies point to mass surveillance of Uighurs as well as physical and verbal abuse, indoctrination, and “<a href="https://apnews.com/269b3de1af34e17c1941a514f78d764c?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">demographic genocide</a>” (reducing birth rates through forced birth control, sterilization, and abortions). </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Human rights advocates call it China’s worst abuse in decades, and foreign governments have pressured Beijing to stop.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">It's a big deal for businesses</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Importing goods produced by forced labor is a violation of federal law. In July, President Trump <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2019/10/07/trump-china-uighur-surveillance-038309?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">added</a> 11 companies with ties to alleged human rights violations to the blacklist, affecting a supplier for apparel brands including Ralph Lauren and Hugo Boss. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>A recent NYT </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/19/world/asia/china-mask-forced-labor.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">investigation</a></span><span> found at least 17 Xinjiang companies use Uighur labor to produce medical-grade face masks sold in the U.S.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, the White House said it <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/u-weighs-barring-products-cotton-033756220.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">banned imports</a> from a trio of companies in Xinjiang and plans to add six more to the list targeting cotton, textiles, and tomatoes. Xinjiang <a href="https://uhrp.org/news-commentary/report-released-cotton-fabric-full-lies?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">produces</a> 84% of China’s cotton and is a top textile and apparel supplier. A ban could have <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/07/business/economy/us-china-xinjiang-cotton-ban.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">major implications</a> for clothing brands and increase pressure to relocate supply chains. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> According to the Uyghur Human Rights Project, “because forced labor is used so ubiquitously throughout Xinjiang...governments, companies, and consumers should assume that any cotton products sourced from China are a product of China’s cotton gulag.”</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
AUTO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/08/gm-nikola-shares-pop-new-partnership-announcement?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Nikola Has a New WinGMan
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Nikola truck" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzQ4L25pa29sYV90cnVjay5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, hallowed Detroit automaker GM announced a $2 billion investment in Nikola, the sexy electric truck shop that <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/13/blank-check-mergers-becoming-lot-common.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">went public</a> in June via reverse merger. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The details</strong>: GM will develop and manufacture Nikola’s new models in exchange for an 11% stake in the company and a seat on the board. Picture Timon and Pumbaa guiding Simba, but instead of eating bugs they’re teaching him how to install fuel cells. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>GM stock popped almost 8% on the news; Nikola jumped nearly 41%. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>One problem to solve later: Nikola’s Badger truck, which GM </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/08/general-motors-takes-11percent-stake-and-2-billion-in-equity-in-electric-truck-maker-nikola-.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">will help</a></span><span> Nikola produce by late 2022, could eventually compete with GM’s trucks. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>This is yet <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/general-motors-takes-stake-in-electric-vehicle-company-nikola-11599568421?mod=business_lead_pos1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">another example</a> of an established automaker moving into the EV world via supplying components to younger rivals. Ford struck a similar agreement with Rivian last year, and EV startup Fisker also plans to outsource components. There is one exception though, and it’s a big one—Nikola’s last name/rival Tesla is vertically integrated, meaning it hasn't needed to strike the manufacturing partnerships that've become the industry norm.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BANKING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/08/government-relief-programs-may-abused-jpmorgan-warns-employees?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
PPP Stands for Potential Plunder Problems
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="JPMorgan" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MDYvamFtaWVfZGltb24uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>"<a href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/jurvetson/8362210873/" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan Chase</a>" (<a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0/" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">CC BY 2.0</a>) by <a href="https://www.flickr.com/people/jurvetson/" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">jurvetson</a></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, JPMorgan’s operating committee <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/08/jpmorgan-says-some-employees-have-fallen-short-as-bank-probes-abuses-of-government-relief-funds-.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sent an email</a> to all 256,710 employees notifying them that a) someone’s leaving half-eaten bananas in the fridge again and b) the bank’s role in the U.S. government’s pandemic relief programs may have involved some shenanigans. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The email </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-08/jpmorgan-probing-employees-role-in-misuse-of-covid-relief-funds?srnd=premium&sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said</a></span><span> there was evidence of “conduct that does not live up to our business and ethical principles—and may even be illegal” by customers misusing Paycheck Protection Program loans, unemployment benefits, and other programs. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“Some employees have fallen short, too,” it added. An investigation is underway.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">JPMorgan was the biggest issuer of PPP loans, which put the burden on applicants to prove they needed support, rather than on the Treasury or on the banks that serviced the loans. This "honor system" may have allowed some applicants to access funds fraudulently.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> PPP was designed to be a sledgehammer instead of a surgical knife. A June watchdog report found that the program’s vast scale and scrunched timeline may have exposed it to fraud. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD & BEV
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/08/ghost-kitchen-operator-virtual-kitchen-announces-20m-new-funding?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Like Everything Else, Kitchens Go Virtual
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Delivery ordering" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzUxL2RlbGl2ZXJ5X29yZGVyaW5nLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Virtual kitchen startup Virtual Kitchen <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/08/virtual-kitchen-led-by-ex-uber-execs-raises-20-million-from-founders.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">revealed</a> $20 million in new funding yesterday, CNBC reports. Cofounded by former Uber execs, the company provides tech for commercial kitchens that want to ditch water refills and napkin folding to focus specifically on delivery. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Yesterday’s round was led by Keith Rabois at Peter Thiel’s Founders Fund. Last year, famed VC shop Andreessen Horowitz led a $15.3 million round. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>With the "ghost kitchen" market expected to reach $2.6 billion by 2026, competition is getting tougher than a well-done flank steak.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>NYC-based Zuul, which has a partnership with Sweetgreen, raised $9 million in July. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>But the Goliath in the field is CloudKitchens, the ghost kitchen startup created by former Uber CEO Travis Kalanick. It </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/11/07/saudis-reportedly-fund-travis-kalanicks-ghost-kitchen-company?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">raised $400 million</a></span><span> last year. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> Ghost kitchens were earning their sea legs before the pandemic, which shut down in-person dining and supercharged growth. But they can still be risky, forcing restaurants to partner with delivery services and relying on delivery app promotions. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ELECTRONICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/08/peloton-microsoft-apple-give-hardware-updates?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Toy Story 2020
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Xbox" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzUyL3hib3guanBlZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Microsoft</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Fall means flannel, a pause in chlorophyll production, and new hardware. Let’s talk about the latest gadget announcements. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Microsoft: </strong>What is this...an Xbox for ants? Microsoft <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/9/8/21426934/microsoft-xbox-series-s-announcement-price?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">confirmed rumors</a> of the “smallest Xbox ever,” the Series S, which will cost $299 in the U.S. It will reportedly <a href="https://www.windowscentral.com/xbox-series-x-and-xbox-series-s-release-date-and-price-finally-revealed?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">be released</a> with the high-end Xbox Series X ($499) on November 10. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Peloton: </strong>The fitness brand is <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/9/8/21427003/peloton-new-treadmill-bike-plus-exercise-equipment-features-price?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">expanding its lineup</a> to include a dramatically cheaper treadmill ($2,495) and a more expensive stationary bike ($2,495)—while dropping the price of its current bike to $1,895.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The company is trying to 1) appeal to a </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/peloton-rides-covid-19-wave-adding-products-cutting-bike-price-11599561900?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wider user base</a></span><span> and 2) manage relentless demand during the pandemic. Prepare yourself for monster fiscal Q4 earnings on Thursday. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Apple: </strong>The company sent invites for a <a href="https://www.axios.com/apple-sets-sept-15-virtual-event-but-may-not-be-for-iphone-a9a248dc-22a6-4359-87e8-0185bd0888c1.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">press event</a> on September 15, but the new iPhone probably won’t make an appearance. Considering the event title is “Time Flies,” analysts think it could be a showcase for the new Apple Watch. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Sales at electronics and appliance stores dominated other retail categories in July, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/08/14/retail-sales-july-2020/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">surging 23%</a>.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In this trivia section, we show you a <a href="https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/2050-Laurel-Canyon-Blvd-Los-Angeles-CA-90046/20802476_zpid/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">current home listing</a> on Zillow, and you have to determine the price of the listing. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Presenting...a 4-bed, 4-bath charmer in the Hollywood Hills. The 4,028-square-foot home was <a href="https://www.latimes.com/business/real-estate/story/2020-09-04/hollywood-hills-home-with-a-full-cast-of-former-owners-hits-the-market?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">originally built</a> for the silent film actress Claire Windsor in 1923, but now has plenty of modern amenities including a heated pool, sauna, and an outdoor kitchen. </p>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzUwL2h1bWFuX3JpZ2h0c19hY3RpdmlzdHNfcHJvdGVzdF9jYW1wc19pbl94aW5qaWFuZy5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003ePierre Crom/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you made it to the credits of Disney’s \u003cem\u003eMulan\u003c/em\u003e remake this weekend, you probably skipped right over the customary \"thank yous\" hoping for a bonus scene. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut some eagle-eyed viewers spotted \u003ca href=\"https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-under-fire-for-filming-mulan-in-chinas-xinjiang-province?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003econtroversial nods\u003c/a\u003e to eight government entities in China’s western Xinjiang region, where part of the movie was filmed. Those entities include multiple propaganda agencies on a White House blacklist for links to forced labor and human rights abuses. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat’s going on in Xinjiang?\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s where China’s Communist Party \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/08/world/asia/china-mulan-xinjiang.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehas detained\u003c/a\u003e an estimated 1+ million ethnic minorities, particularly Uighur Muslims.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eChina claims it's running job-training centers and combating Islamic extremism. But numerous reports, leaks, and testimonies point to mass surveillance of Uighurs as well as physical and verbal abuse, indoctrination, and “\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/269b3de1af34e17c1941a514f78d764c?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edemographic genocide\u003c/a\u003e” (reducing birth rates through forced birth control, sterilization, and abortions). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHuman rights advocates call it China’s worst abuse in decades, and foreign governments have pressured Beijing to stop.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIt's a big deal for businesses\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eImporting goods produced by forced labor is a violation of federal law. In July, President Trump \u003ca href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2019/10/07/trump-china-uighur-surveillance-038309?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eadded\u003c/a\u003e 11 companies with ties to alleged human rights violations to the blacklist, affecting a supplier for apparel brands including Ralph Lauren and Hugo Boss. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eA recent NYT \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/19/world/asia/china-mask-forced-labor.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einvestigation\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e found at least 17 Xinjiang companies use Uighur labor to produce medical-grade face masks sold in the U.S.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, the White House said it \u003ca href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/u-weighs-barring-products-cotton-033756220.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebanned imports\u003c/a\u003e from a trio of companies in Xinjiang and plans to add six more to the list targeting cotton, textiles, and tomatoes. Xinjiang \u003ca href=\"https://uhrp.org/news-commentary/report-released-cotton-fabric-full-lies?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eproduces\u003c/a\u003e 84% of China’s cotton and is a top textile and apparel supplier. A ban could have \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/07/business/economy/us-china-xinjiang-cotton-ban.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emajor implications\u003c/a\u003e for clothing brands and increase pressure to relocate supply chains. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e According to the Uyghur Human Rights Project, “because forced labor is used so ubiquitously throughout Xinjiang...governments, companies, and consumers should assume that any cotton products sourced from China are a product of China’s cotton gulag.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, hallowed Detroit automaker GM announced a $2 billion investment in Nikola, the sexy electric truck shop that \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/13/blank-check-mergers-becoming-lot-common.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewent public\u003c/a\u003e in June via reverse merger. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe details\u003c/strong\u003e: GM will develop and manufacture Nikola’s new models in exchange for an 11% stake in the company and a seat on the board. Picture Timon and Pumbaa guiding Simba, but instead of eating bugs they’re teaching him how to install fuel cells. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eGM stock popped almost 8% on the news; Nikola jumped nearly 41%. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eOne problem to solve later: Nikola’s Badger truck, which GM \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/08/general-motors-takes-11percent-stake-and-2-billion-in-equity-in-electric-truck-maker-nikola-.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewill help\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Nikola produce by late 2022, could eventually compete with GM’s trucks. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThis is yet \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/general-motors-takes-stake-in-electric-vehicle-company-nikola-11599568421?mod=business_lead_pos1\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eanother example\u003c/a\u003e of an established automaker moving into the EV world via supplying components to younger rivals. Ford struck a similar agreement with Rivian last year, and EV startup Fisker also plans to outsource components. There is one exception though, and it’s a big one—Nikola’s last name/rival Tesla is vertically integrated, meaning it hasn't needed to strike the manufacturing partnerships that've become the industry style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, JPMorgan’s operating committee \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/08/jpmorgan-says-some-employees-have-fallen-short-as-bank-probes-abuses-of-government-relief-funds-.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esent an email\u003c/a\u003e to all 256,710 employees notifying them that a) someone’s leaving half-eaten bananas in the fridge again and b) the bank’s role in the U.S. government’s pandemic relief programs may have involved some shenanigans. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe email \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-08/jpmorgan-probing-employees-role-in-misuse-of-covid-relief-funds?srnd=premium\u0026sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e there was evidence of “conduct that does not live up to our business and ethical principles—and may even be illegal” by customers misusing Paycheck Protection Program loans, unemployment benefits, and other programs. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“Some employees have fallen short, too,” it added. An investigation is underway.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eJPMorgan was the biggest issuer of PPP loans, which put the burden on applicants to prove they needed support, rather than on the Treasury or on the banks that serviced the loans. This \"honor system\" may have allowed some applicants to access funds fraudulently.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e PPP was designed to be a sledgehammer instead of a surgical knife. collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eVirtual kitchen startup Virtual Kitchen \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/08/virtual-kitchen-led-by-ex-uber-execs-raises-20-million-from-founders.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erevealed\u003c/a\u003e $20 million in new funding yesterday, CNBC reports. Cofounded by former Uber execs, the company provides tech for commercial kitchens that want to ditch water refills and napkin folding to focus specifically on delivery. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eYesterday’s round was led by Keith Rabois at Peter Thiel’s Founders Fund. Last year, famed VC shop Andreessen Horowitz led a $15.3 million round. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eWith the \"ghost kitchen\" market expected to reach $2.6 billion by 2026, competition is getting tougher than a well-done flank steak.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNYC-based Zuul, which has a partnership with Sweetgreen, raised $9 million in July. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eBut the Goliath in the field is CloudKitchens, the ghost kitchen startup created by former Uber CEO Travis Kalanick. It \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/11/07/saudis-reportedly-fund-travis-kalanicks-ghost-kitchen-company?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eraised $400 million\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e last year. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e Ghost kitchens were earning their sea legs before the pandemic, which shut down in-person dining and supercharged growth.
